translated: Jātaka🔽The Collection of Middle-Length Discourses
The Group of Discourses with Similes
The Story of Vijjādhara
“You are ugly, with the color of a noble one,
With palms joined, you pay homage, placing him in front.

original: Seyyo nu te so udavā sarikkho,
analyzed: seyyaḥ nu te saḥ udavā sarikkho
translated: Is he better than you, or are you equal?
Tell me your name and his.”
“They don’t take names, King,
The gods who follow the right path.
I’ll tell you my name,
I am Sakka, lord of the Thirty-Three.”
“Having seen a monk who has attained the feet,
With palms joined, you pay homage, placing him in front.
I ask you, god of gods, about this matter:

original: Ito cuto kiṁ labhate sukhaṁ so”.
analyzed: itas cutas kim labhate sukham saḥ
translated: What happiness does he get after dying here?”

analyzed: yaḥ disvā bhikkhum caraṇūpapanna  purakkhatvā pañjalikaḥ namassati
translated: “Having seen a monk who has attained the feet,🔽With palms joined, you pay homage, placing him in front.
In this very life he gets praise,

analyzed: saggam ca saḥ yāti sarīra bhedā
translated: And after the break-up of the body, he goes to heaven.”
“Today a good thought has arisen for me,
That I’ve seen Vāsava, lord of the bhūtas.
Having seen a monk and you, Sakka,
I’ll make much merit.”
“Surely the wise should be served,

analyzed: bahu ssutāḥ ye bahu ṭhāna cintinaḥ
translated: The learned who have thought much on many things.
Seeing the monk and me, O King,
Make you much merit.”
“Free from anger, always cheerful,
Having given up all pride,
I will bow down, having heard these good sayings, O Lord of the Devas.”
The Birth Story of Vijjadhara (the Sixth) is finished.
